messages.content: Does my dell G15 5520 support PCIE gen 4 ssds?

The Dell G15 5520 gaming laptop supports PCIe Gen 3 NVMe solid state drives, but not the latest PCIe Gen 4 SSDs.

The G15 5520 has two M.2 slots for SSDs:

- Slot 1 supports PCIe Gen 3 x4 NVMe SSDs. This is the primary drive slot.
- Slot 2 also supports PCIe Gen 3 x4 NVMe SSDs. This can be used as a secondary storage drive.

PCIe Gen 4 SSDs are not supported and will not run at Gen 4 speeds in this laptop. They will operate at PCIe Gen 3 speeds if installed.

So you can install fast PCIe 3.0 NVMe SSDs like:

- Samsung 970 EVO Plus 
- WD Black SN750
- Crucial P5 
- SK hynix Gold P31

But PCIe 4.0 SSDs like:

- Samsung 980 Pro
- WD Black SN850 
- Seagate FireCuda 530

Will run at PCIe 3.0 speeds in this Dell G15.

For most users and gaming workloads though, a high performance PCIe 3.0 SSD will still provide very fast storage speeds and good performance in this laptop. So while PCIe 4.0 is not supported, you can get an excellent SSD upgrade experience with the latest high end Gen 3 drives.

Hope this helps! Let me know if you have any other questions.
So I cannot upgrade from my NVMe BC711 NVMe SK hynix 512GB?

You can definitely upgrade from the stock SK hynix BC711 NVMe 512GB SSD in your Dell G15 5520. That is a basic PCIe 3.0 NVMe drive.

You have a couple of good upgrade options:

1. Upgrade to a faster, higher capacity PCIe 3.0 NVMe SSD. Something like:

- Samsung 970 EVO Plus 1TB - Faster speeds, double the capacity. Around $150.

- WD Black SN750 1TB - One of the fastest PCIe 3.0 SSDs, around $150. 

- Crucial P5 2TB - For a big boost in storage capacity, around $230.

These will give you a nice speed and capacity upgrade from your current SK hynix SSD.

2. Install a second PCIe 3.0 NVMe SSD in your empty M.2 slot. Something like a 1TB or 2TB drive. This will give you more total storage in your laptop. You can then move your Windows and programs to the faster drive and use the other for storage.

3. Replace your stock 512GB SK hynix drive with a higher capacity PCIe 4.0 SSD. While it won't run at the full Gen 4 speeds, it will still work at Gen 3 speeds and provide more storage. Something like:

- Samsung 980 Pro 1TB - Around $170, will run at PCIe 3.0 speeds in your laptop.

- WD Black SN850 1TB - Around $140, also runs at Gen 3 speeds but provides more storage.

Any of these options would provide an upgrade from your current 512GB SK hynix BC711 drive. Faster Gen 3 SSDs, more storage from a second SSD or larger capacity Gen 4 drives are all good ways to improve your laptop storage.

Let me know if you have any other questions!
Do you think that a NVMe BC711 NVMe SK hynix 512GB can be a bottleneck in games,AI inference or video transcoding? Is it a decent SSD?

The SK hynix BC711 NVMe 512GB SSD is a basic entry-level PCIe 3.0 NVMe drive. While it will work fine as a boot drive for general use, it could potentially bottleneck certain intensive tasks like:

• Gaming - When gaming, assets have to be loaded from storage into memory very quickly. A faster, higher performance SSD can improve load times and reduce stuttering for a better gaming experience. The BC711 will work, but a faster SSD may perform better.

• AI inference - Training and running AI models requires reading and writing a lot of data very quickly. A higher performance SSD can help speed up AI workflows.

• Video transcoding - Converting high resolution video files strains the storage system. A faster SSD will perform better for intensive video editing and transcoding tasks.

So while the SK hynix BC711 is a decent, serviceable SSD for everyday use as a boot drive, for intensive tasks like gaming, AI workloads and 4K video editing, a higher performance SSD may provide better performance and a more responsive experience.

Some good higher performance PCIe 3.0 upgrade options would be:

• Samsung 970 EVO Plus - Up to 3,500/3,300 MB/s reads/writes. Around $120 for 1TB.

• WD Black SN750 - Up to 3,400/2,900 MB/s. Around $150 for 1TB.

• Crucial P5 - Up to 3,400/3,000 MB/s. Around $110 for 1TB.

• Seagate FireCuda 520 - Up to 5,000/4,400 MB/s. Around $200 for 1TB.

Any of these drives would provide substantially faster speeds and more responsiveness than the SK hynix BC711 for gaming and intensive workloads. So if you're noticing bottlenecks or slowdowns, an SSD upgrade could help significantly improve performance.

Hope this helps! Let me know if you have any other questions.
